channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [TIKA-1387] Add forbidden-apis checker to TIKA build
item.description:
Lucene and many other projects already use the forbidden-apis checker to prevent use of some broken classes/signatures from the JDK. These are especially thing using default character sets or default locales. The forbidden-api checker can also be used to explcitely disallow specific methods, if they have security issues (e.g., creating XML parsers without disabling external entity support).

The attached patch adds the forbidden-api checker to the tika-parent pom file with default configuration.

Running it fails with many errors in TIKA core already:

[INFO] --- forbiddenapis:1.6.1:check (default) @ tika-core ---
[INFO] Scanning for classes to check...
[INFO] Reading bundled API signatures: jdk-unsafe

[INFO] Scanning for API signatures and dependencies...

We should fix those problems.
item.summary: Add forbidden-apis checker to TIKA build

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Patch with Maven config.

This patch refactors the tika-java7 module a bit, so the forbidden-api checker also uses the correct signatures (Java 7). This was done by redefining the parent-pom properties instead of duplicating the compiler and forbidden plugins.

One suggestion:
The official name of the properties for source/target are: "maven.compile*r*.target" and "maven.compile*r*.source". I would suggest to change those. If this is dane, you can remove the explicit declaration in the plugin properties, because the maven compiler plugin and the maven forbiddenapis plugin read those properties.
Patch with renamed properties to conform to Maven standards.
I will take a look at these and fix the issues in Tika core today. Thank you for the help, Uwe!
thanks guys

Here is a patch which includes the forbiddenapi Maven updates and fixes all errors currently identified by the plugin.

This ended up being a pretty big set of changes. So, can someone else review and test (esp. in a different timezone from Pacific)? I uploaded a review here: https://reviews.apache.org/r/24399/
Fixed in r1616295. Thanks Uwe Schindler!

Hi I left a comment in the review. Was out for dinner. I would fix the issues in a different way at some places. Especially String#toLowerCase(Locale.getDefault()), which has crazy effects in some languages (in Turkish not even ASCII lower cases as expected).
I disagree wth some fixes, because they just workaround the forbidden-checks by still using system defaults.

Thanks Uwe. Tyler Palsulich can always work with you and update as makes sense per the review board. This is just an initial commit. I'm not going to do the RC #2 probably for another day or so anyways since I want to get one more translator in there (the ExternalTranslator) that Tyler is working on.

ABORTED: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.7 #147 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.7/147/)
Fix for TIKA-1387 (thanks Uwe Schindler). Adding the Maven forbidden-apis plugin and fixing identified errors. (tpalsulich: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1616295)

SUCCESS: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.7 #152 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.7/152/)
Disabling the forbidden-apis plugin until TIKA-1387 is resolved. (tpalsulich: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1616864)

  • /tika/trunk/tika-parent/pom.xml

SUCCESS: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.6 #130 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.6/130/)
Disabling the forbidden-apis plugin until TIKA-1387 is resolved. (tpalsulich: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1616864)

  • /tika/trunk/tika-parent/pom.xml

I have gone through the changes which used Locale.getDefault(), and updated those to use Locale.ROOT where formatting numbers / ascii messages / doing case operations on ascii style text. That should all be fine now as of r1617765.

I haven't touched the recently added getDefault's for Charset or Timezone, those still need doing

In some places, a try/catch around charset was added, when working with UTF-8. A JVM is always required to provide UTF-8, so these places can be simplified as UnsupportedEncodingException can never be thrown for UTF-8

There are also a few places with SimpleDateFormat, which I've done a quick review of for thread safety. I think the only one that's a problem is PDF2XHTML

SUCCESS: Integrated in tika-trunk-jdk1.6 #136 (See https://builds.apache.org/job/tika-trunk-jdk1.6/136/)
For places formatting numbers in fixed formats, or case-insensitive comparing Ascii strings, use Locale.ROOT not Locale.getDefault() to ensure predictable behaviour, and avoid issues in locales like Turkish. TIKA-1387 (nick: http://svn.apache.org/viewvc/tika/trunk/?view=rev&rev=1617765)

I had these changes locally, but you beat me to it! I'm seeing a few Locale.ENGLISH. Should we be using Locale.ROOT for those, too?

I think, for "messages" written in english language (like those written to logs), ENGLISH is "more" correct. But it does not really matter.

About the charsets:
I would define a constant in IOUtils public final Charset UTF_8 = Charset.forName("UTF-8"); and then pass this to all methods that accept it (like Readers, String,...). This is also faster than a sychronized String lookup on every conversion, like done by the standard default charset or String charset parameter.

Java 7 has StandardCharsets.UTF_8 but we cannot use this at the moment. But its defined like the one I propose for IOUtils.
